title: Biaxially oriented polypropylene pipes: implications for impact and hydrostatic pressure resistance.
abstract: NoThe Leeds die drawing process has been used to produce biaxially oriented polypropylene pipes with significant enhancement of hoop mechanical properties in terms of tensile modulus and tensile strength owing to a unique orientation of the ¿ crystallites throughout their cross-section. Pendulum impact tests on these pipes show major improvements in impact resistance. Hydrostatic pressure tests were undertaken at room temperature 95 and 110°C. Major improvements in behaviour were found including more than an order of magnitude increase in lifetime at 95°C. Furthermore, the toughness was improved enormously leading to a brittle tough transition temperature below ¿70°C

Biaxially oriented polypropylene pipes: implications for impact and hydrostatic pressure resistance.</dc:title><dc:creator>
Morath, C.C,</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Ward, Ian M.</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Soliman, M.</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Voets, P.</dc:creator><dc:creator>
Kleppinger, R.</dc:creator><dc:subject>
Oriented polypropylene pipes</dc:subject><dc:subject>
Impact</dc:subject><dc:subject>
Pressure resistance</dc:subject><dc:description>
No</dc:description><dc:description>
The Leeds die drawing process has been used to produce biaxially oriented polypropylene pipes with significant enhancement of hoop mechanical properties in terms of tensile modulus and tensile strength owing to a unique orientation of the ¿ crystallites throughout their cross-section. Pendulum impact tests on these pipes show major improvements in impact resistance. Hydrostatic pressure tests were undertaken at room temperature 95 and 110°C. Major improvements in behaviour were found including more than an order of magnitude increase in lifetime at 95°C. Furthermore, the toughness was improved enormously leading to a brittle tough transition temperature below ¿70°C.</dc:description><dc:date>
